questions.qText: The wavelength of light coming from a sodium source is 589 nm in vacuum (or air). Its wavelength in water is [Refractive index of water = 4/3]
In the above question, the frequency of light in vacuum and water are respectively
Which of the following is not an essential condition for sustained interference of light waves
qOptions: The two interfering waves must be propagated in almost the same direction or must intersect at very small angle.
The waves must have the same period and wavelength.
The amplitude of the two waves must be equal.
The two interfering beams of light must originate from the same source.

questions.qText: When a wave is refracted,

Two waves create sinusoidal displacements at a point represented by \(y_1 = 10\sin(2000\pi t)\) and \(y_2 = 20\sin(2000\pi t + \pi/2)\). The amplitude of the resultant SHM of that point is _____. (Options are made-up distractors; one is correct.)

Two coherent point sources of sound wave \(S_1\) and \(S_2\) produce sound of same frequency 50 Hz and wavelength 2 cm with amplitude \(2\times10^{-3}\,\text{m}\). Each circular arc represents a wavefront at a particular time and is separated from next arc by a distance 1 cm. Both sound waves propagate through the medium and interfere with each other. Bold circular lines denote wavefront of \(S_1\) and dotted circular lines denote wavefront of \(S_2\).
The points of minimum intensity will occur at
How many of the points shown in the figure represent maxima

A radio station operating at a frequency of 1.5 MHz has two identical vertical dipole antennas spaced 400 m apart oscillating in the same phase. Choose the correct statements. [Given \(c = 3\times10^8\,\text{m/s},\; \cos(2\pi\sin4^{\circ}) = \sqrt{0.8}\)]
qOptions: At distances ≫ 400 m, if \(\theta = \pm30^{\circ}\), the intensity will be greatest.
At distances ≫ 400 m, if \(\theta = \pm60^{\circ}\), the intensity will be greatest.
If antennas are 10 m apart and frequency 60 MHz, intensity at \(P\) (700 m on y-axis, \(\theta=0^{\circ}\)) is 0.020 W m⁻²; then at \(A\) (\(\theta=4^{\circ}\)) it is 0.008 W m⁻².
Same as above but intensity at \(A\) is 0.016 W m⁻².

questions.qText: In a YDSE experiment, distance between two slits is \(4.7\lambda\). The number of points on the screen having maximum and zero brightness are respectively
If the distance between the slits was \(4.2\lambda\), then the answer would be
In a YDSE experiment, distance between two slits is \(5\lambda\). Choose the correct statement(s).
qOptions: Angular separation between \(n\)th and \((n+1)\)th maxima increases with \(n\).
Angular separation between \(n\)th and \((n+1)\)th maxima decreases with \(n\).
Distance between \(n\)th and \((n+1)\)th maxima on screen increases with \(n\).
Distance between \(n\)th and \((n+1)\)th maxima on screen decreases with \(n\).

questions.qText: In a YDSE experiment, distance between two slits is \(5\lambda\). The distance between 4th and 3rd maxima from the central maxima on the same side is
In the above question, the distance of 1st dark spot from the central bright spot is
In the above question, the location of 3rd dark spot from the central bright spot is

Two identical coherent sources of wavelength \(\lambda\) are placed at \((100\lambda, 0)\) and \((-50\lambda, 0)\). A detector moves from origin to \((50\lambda, 0)\) along x-axis. The number of maxima and minima detected respectively are

Interference is observed due to two coherent sources ‘A’ and ‘B’ having phase constant 0, separated by a distance \(6\lambda\) along y-axis. A detector D moves along x-axis. Number of points (excluding x = 0 and ∞) where maximum occurs is
qOptions: 6 if both A and B have positive Y and A at (0, 2λ)
2 if A has positive Y and B negative Y, A at (0, 2λ)
1 if A has positive Y and B negative Y, A at (0, 2.2λ)
5 if A has positive Y and B negative Y, A at (0, 2.2λ)

questions.qText: Two coherent sources \(S_1\) and \(S_2\) separated by \(2\lambda\) emit light of wavelength \(\lambda\) in phase as shown. A circular wire of radius \(100\lambda\) is placed so that \(S_1S_2\) lies in its plane and midpoint of \(S_1S_2\) is at the centre. Find the angular position \(\theta\) on the wire for which intensity reduces to half of maximum.
O is the center of a circular screen and \(S_1, S_2\) are two coherent point sources of light separated by \(5\lambda\). Find number of maxima on screen.
In the above question, number of minima on the screen is
In a YDSE, if separation between slits and screen are halved and doubled respectively, the fringe width will be
With two slits spaced 0.2 mm apart and a screen at 1 m, the third bright fringe is 7.5 mm from center. The wavelength is
In the above question, the distance between the 4th bright fringe on one side of central maxima and 5th dark fringe on the other side is
The total number of maxima that can be formed on a large screen (excluding the bright spots at infinity) is

In a Young’s double slit experiment, 12 fringes are observed in a certain segment of the screen when light of wavelength \(600\,\text{nm}\) is used. If the wavelength of light is changed to \(400\,\text{nm}\), the number of fringes observed in the same segment of the screen is
In a double slit experiment, the distance between the slits is \(d\). The screen is at a distance \(D\). If a bright fringe is formed directly opposite a slit, the order of fringe is

In Young’s double slit experiment, the slits are separated by \(0.3\,\text{mm}\) and the interference pattern is observed on a screen placed \(100\,\text{cm}\) away. The wavelength of light used is \(6000\,\text{Å}\). Choose the correct statements.
qOptions: The distance of 4th bright fringe from the central fringe is 8 mm.
The distance of 4th dark fringe from the central fringe is 7 mm.
The distance between the 9th dark and 2nd bright fringe on same side is 15 mm.
The distance between the first dark and second bright fringes on opposite sides is 5 mm.

questions.qText: A beam of light consisting of two wavelengths \(6500\,\text{Å}\) and \(5200\,\text{Å}\) is used in a Young’s double slit experiment. The least distance from the central maximum where bright fringes due to both wavelengths coincide is (\(d=2\,\text{mm}\), \(D=120\,\text{cm}\)). (Options are made-up distractors; one is correct.)
If the screen is shifted in \(x\)-direction away from the source, which of the following is incorrect?
qOptions: Central maxima is shifted along y-axis
Position of all maxima except the central maxima change
Angular width changes due to shifting

questions.qText: In a Young’s double slit experiment, the separation between the slits is \(0.10\,\text{mm}\), the wavelength of light used is \(6000\,\text{Å}\), and the interference pattern is observed on a screen \(1.0\,\text{m}\) away. The separation between successive bright fringes is

In Young’s experiment, wavelength of red light is \(7.8\times10^{-7}\,\text{m}\) and that of blue light is \(5.2\times10^{-7}\,\text{m}\). Find \(n\) for which \((n+1)\)th blue fringe coincides with nth red fringe. If \(d=2\,\text{mm}\) and \(D=2\,\text{m}\), find least distance from central maxima where both colors overlap.

In a Young’s double slit experiment, the slits are illuminated by two wavelengths of \(400\,\text{nm}\) and \(600\,\text{nm}\). If \(d=1\,\text{mm}\), \(D=10\,\text{m}\), the smallest distance from the central maximum where there is complete darkness is:
A Young’s double slit experiment is performed with white light. Then
qOptions: The central brightness will be red
The brightness next to central will be red
The central brightness will be violet
The brightness next to central will be violet

questions.qText: In a YDSE, bi-chromatic light of wavelengths \(400\,\text{nm}\) and \(560\,\text{nm}\) are used. The distance between the slits is \(0.1\,\text{mm}\) and between the slits and screen is \(1\,\text{m}\). The minimum distance between two successive regions of complete darkness is

A parallel beam of light consisting of two wavelengths \(14000\,\text{Å}\) and \(26000\,\text{Å}\) falls on a double slit apparatus. The separation between the two slits is \(2\,\text{mm}\) and between the plane of the slits and the screen is \(1\,\text{m}\). Find the location of the central maxima for both wavelengths and the point where their maxima coincide for the first time after central maxima. (Options are made-up distractors; one is correct.)

White light is used to illuminate two slits in Young’s double slit experiment. The separation between slits is \(b\) and screen is at a distance \(d\). At a point directly in front of one slit, certain wavelengths are missing. The missing wavelength is:
In a YDSE, \(D\) equals the distance of the screen and \(d\) is slit separation. The distance of the nearest point to central maximum where the intensity is same as that due to a single slit is:
In a double slit experiment, initially both slits had width \(W\). Now one slit’s width is reduced. Then in the interference pattern:
qOptions: The intensities of both maxima and minima increase
The intensity of maxima increases and minima have zero intensity
The intensity of maxima decreases and minima increase
The intensity of maxima decreases and minima have zero intensity

questions.qText: In a Young’s double slit experiment, the path difference of waves for a point P on screen is one-third of wavelength. The ratio of intensity at P to that at maximum is:

In Young’s experiment, the slits (\(d = 0.8\,\text{mm}\)) are illuminated with light of \(7200\,\text{Å}\). Interference pattern is obtained on a screen \(2\,\text{m}\) from slits. Find the minimum distance from central maximum at which intensity is 50% of maximum.

Two identical glass plates reflect 20% of light incident on them and rest is transmitted. If slits are illuminated with equal intensity, the ratio of minimum to maximum intensity in interference pattern formed is:

Two beams of light having intensities \(I\) and \(4I\) interfere to produce a fringe pattern. The phase difference between beams is \(\pi/2\) at A and \(\pi\) at B. The ratio of resultant intensities at A and B is:
In Young’s experiment, light of wavelength \(600\,\text{nm}\) falls on double slits separated by \(0.1\,\text{mm}\). What is the highest order of maximum observed on screen kept \(3\,\text{m}\) away?
Two light waves of intensities \(I_0\) and \(4I_0\) interfere at a point P. The maximum and minimum intensities produced are:
In a YDSE arrangement, the intensity at the central maximum is \(I\). When either of the two slits is closed, intensity becomes \(I_0\). Then:
In a Young’s double slit experiment, contrast between fringes is given by \(I_{\max}:I_{\min} = 9:4\). The ratio of intensities of the two sources is:

In a modified YDSE, a monochromatic uniform parallel beam of wavelength \(6000\,\text{Å}\) and intensity \(\tfrac{10}{\pi}\,\text{W/m}^2\) is incident normally on two circular apertures A and B of radii 1 mm and 2 mm respectively. Find the ratio of intensities of two sources \(\tfrac{I_B}{I_A}\). (Options are made-up distractors; one is correct.)
In a usual YDSE, if average intensity between \(y_1 = \tfrac{\lambda D}{4d}\) and \(y_2 = +\tfrac{\lambda D}{4d}\) equals \(n\) times the intensity of maxima, then \(n\) equals

In YDSE, \(d/D = 10^{-4}\) and \(\lambda = 600\,\text{nm}\). At a point P, resulting intensity equals that due to one slit. Find minimum distance of point P from central maximum in mm. (Options are made-up distractors; one is correct.)
